Closing this. I just now saw that jigish's Slate is dead, and the maintained fork at mattr/slate already has the relevant doc updates.

Xcode 8.2.1

If not this project is not live anymore ...and thats a pitty

I noticed there is no default binding for grid behavior. Even though it was not hard to configure, seeing as this is intended as a replacement application for Divvy, it would be ideal for users with less programming experience to have a default binding for the grid.
After upgrading to sierra, when I launch slate it asks me the access question. I click enable, it doesn't prompt me for my admin password, and the slate icon disappears from my menubar.

I was able to set up slate for macOS Sierra 10.12.

You may have to go to System Preferences>Security & Privacy>Accessibility

Then check the box next to Slate.app

After doing this slate should have access, and should run smoothly. Let me know if you're still having issues.
That did it, thanks!

Guys, refer this post: https://github.com/jigish/slate/issues/437

`jigish/slate` is not maintained anymore


Please use and contribute to: 

# [mattr-/slate](https://github.com/mattr-/slate)

Hi all!

I've created a localized version of the slate keyboard layout for [qwertz_de keyboards here](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/the-holger/slate_qwertz_de/master/ASCIIToCode_Qwertz_de.plist).

As "dumb" testing (i.e. replacing the ASCIIToCode.plist with my file) worked fine I wanted to fork the slate repo and create a proper "enhancement" to contribute to slate, I'm running into problems however:

- Cloned repo and opened project file in XCode
- Dragged and dropped my plist to Slate/Common and copying it there
- Added new layout to Common/Constants.[m|h] and Config/Binding.m
- (Fixed two deprecations in JSONkit.m automatically)
- Built & ran Slate => 
  - "Unrecognized Key" for my additions
  - My plist is missing from the Contents/Resources folder (even though it's included in "Copy Bundle Resources").

Anyway, hope the keyboard layout is of use. If anybody has a hint what I am missing here I'd be happy to learn!

Cheers!
Holger
default.slate should not bind ⌘←, ⌘→, ⌘↓, and ⌘↑ as these are used for navigation in text areas. The keys used here should be something else.

It took about 8 awful hours to detect the problem. 
Sad, but I had to delete Slate because I can't code with the tool running.
This issue is tracking not having these on by default. The default.slate file can still be modified by you to workaround this issue.
When activating the grid, it doesn't seem to be dismissible without resizing a window. You should be able to cancel the grid using the modalEscapeKey.

👍 These are much improved!

Could the blue color used in statusActive.pdf be a bit darker to provide a little bit more contrast?
It needs to work with both the light (default) chrome and dark chrome, but tweaking it doesn't take long.

I think the color used for selection/highlighting in the menu bar (`[NSColor selectedMenuItemColor]`, which roughly equates to #187AEE) is probably best. This color could be burned into the image, but should likely be done programmatically to ensure that it gets the proper treatment when high contrast mode is enabled (System Preferences > Accessibility > Display > Increase Contrast).

Additionally, to provide more visual contrast against the normal state, I made the normal state outlined, and the active state filled. I feel the outlined style also fits in better with the other status item icons.
[status.pdf](https://github.com/jigish/slate/files/609693/status.pdf)
[statusActive.pdf](https://github.com/jigish/slate/files/609694/statusActive.pdf)

Thanks @mdznr, changed the color of the active state!

Typically, status bar icons don't change visually between active and default state, they just get a different color treatment, so I didn't make that change.

Updated graphics and screenshots.
![black](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13096/20579434/587bef26-b181-11e6-8932-2fe7e3de80ac.png)
![white](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13096/20579433/587a795c-b181-11e6-9628-3efdbed21403.png)

Since I upgraded to OSX 10.12 Sierra, it takes 9 seconds from pressing the hotkey to the window resizing, in an application that I just command-tabbed to. After the first resize, everything is normal. If I switch to another application, then switch back, the first resize takes 9 seconds again.

This is an intricate one. The problem went away when I switched from `color-theme-solarized` to `solarized-theme` in Emacs. I had the problem with every application (I suppose as long as Emacs was running), but changing this in Emacs, fixed the problem everywhere.

So this might not be a Slate problem as such. Still, I would be very interested if someone had a hunch why Slate was affected by an Emacs setting. Did it create a lot of windowing data that Slate had to slog through? Did it add any hooks? Emacs doesn't have accessibility access.

I'm also curious why I did not have this problem in OSX 10.11. I did not change my Emacs settings for a long time.
Hm, no, that wasn't it either. I've had long latencies again even after the change. I have some impression it may be related to how many windows I have open.
There is no "Load config" option on the status menu anymore.
My previously working script on Yosemite no longer loads my old snapshot now that I upgraded to Sierra. I also cannot take a new snapshot and load it.
Closing, the issue was that upgrading to Sierra reset the Universal Access settings...once I reenabled, Slate worked fine!

This is a fix so that Slate is able to run shell commands for applications whose names have spaces in them.

This, for example, would not work until this fix: shell '/usr/bin/open -a "/Applications/Sublime Text.app"'

Note: simply surround the argument, in this case "/Applications/Sublime Text.app" with double-quotes.

I put a new .slate file in the same directory that holds all my Slate files (on a mac users/my name/documents/slate/Slate) and Slate does not recognize it and is defaulting to the default.slate file in the same directory. I've tried moving the file around as well, to my user folder, to my documents folder, to the slate folder. None of them make a difference.

AFAIK, Slate's default configuration file is still required to exist in your your home folder, and be named ".slate", which requires that you use an application other than Finder to put it there or give it that name. Finder, by default won't allow you to view a file having a name that starts with ".", so you must either rename it with a command in the Terminal app, or use an app such as TinkerTool or Onyx which has the ability to modify the Finder's default configuration so that normally hidden files become visible. One more thing, if you make the normally hidden files visible, you'll need to use command-O to open the selected .slate file rather than double-clicking it.

I updated terminal to allow me to see hidden files and I don't see anything hidden in that folder. I have a default.slate file that I downloaded from this project that is in there, but if I edit it nothing happens. I also tried changing it's name to just .slate with nothing preceding the period, but it made no difference. Slate just doesn't see it. I also tried moving it (named .slate) to my home folder (Users/my name) and it made no difference.

I got it to work! Turns out just moving the file in finder didn't do the trick. I opened up filezilla checked it and the file name was actually .slate.slate, but finder was just saying it was .slate. I shortened it to the right name and it worked!

I have now successfully used Slate in El Capitan. After the upgrade Slate seemed broken. It asked me for some "accessibility" permission but granting this permission did nothing. I was able to fix the problem and make Slate work again by doing as follows.
1. go to  → System Preferences → Security & Privacy → Accessibility
2. click on lock icon to unlock settings
3. enter user password when prompted for it
4. check the checkbox next to Slate
5. click on lock icon to lock settings
6. close settings window 
7. quit slate by clicking on the slate icon at the top of the screen and selecting "Quit Slate"
8. press ⌘ + space to bring up application launcher
9. type "slate" and hit the return key to launch Slate

Open the terminal app. In there type the following commands one by one:

cd $HOME
touch .slate
open -a textedit .slate

The last command should open an empty file named .slate in the textedit
editor. Now, you can change it all you want, and then save. If you prefer
any other editor, you should be able to open and edit this file like usual.

Thanks. I used TextWrangler. I warned me about saving a file with a dot in front of the name but it did allow me to save it. 

TIP for new users: you can make an alias of the invisible file and drag it to the desktop BUT make sure you remove the dot in the alias name. This way, when you want to access it you just double-click the alias!
@project-guru you can also create an alias with the command `ln -s`, for example `ln -s .original .hidden`.

First of all, my apologies for being _very_ absent over the past couple of years. I've had some serious work-life balance issues and only been contributing to projects I've used for work. That has changed, though.

It has been a while since I first wrote Slate and am planning on pushing a complete rewrite to my github (probably with in ~2 weeks). As it is a complete rewrite, Slate2 will not support many features up front and the config has changed quite a bit. In addition I'm thinking about supporting only Yosemite+ with Slate2. That being said, I will be committing to it very actively to bring it up to speed with Slate.

As far as this version of Slate is concerned I'm happy to do any of the following:
1. add a pointer to @mattr-'s fork to the readme
2. merge a large pull request and give write access to @mattr- 

either works for me, but I will be putting a pointer to Slate2 on the readme once I push it to my github.

again, apologies for my absence.

Another option would be to commit the rewrite into this repository and add a pointer in the readme to @mattr-'s fork for anyone who wants the original slate. I feel like as it was my first foray into OS X development I've learned a _lot_ from it and would like to do a complete rewrite from scratch.

@jigish
- +1 for the Yosemite+ requirement.
- Is your upcoming rewrite in Swift?
- Are you going to use the `JSContext` class instead of a hidden WebView?
- You might wanna ask for some volunteer contributors who can help clean up the Github Issues that have accumulated and maybe help with the readme.
@jigish Also, feel free to use https://github.com/sdegutis/WindowManager as a baseline for your rewrite if you choose Swift.

yes to Swift and `JSContext`. I actually have a lot of the basics written already, just need to implement to more complex stuff. I'll definitely take a look at WindowManager -- thanks!

If we decide to maintain the original Slate here then I'd suggest just wiping all github issues and pull requests with a generic "I'm wiping this please reopen if it is still an issue" message.

@jigish Also, one approach that might be worth considering is to use Lua instead of JS. Lua is very similar to JS semantically, but much easier to integrate with than JSContext. Plus, Apple's rules around converting structures to/from JS are not super well defined, and there are times it will do a different thing than expected. Plus, the ObjC API for it does not integrate with Swift classes, you have to write NSObject-based classes with them. Since Lua has a C API, I wrote a Swift wrapper as https://github.com/sdegutis/lua4swift which you can use if you want. Just throwing it out there as a possibility.
@jigish I'm happy to continue maintaining this version of Slate, so however you want to handle the rewrite, whether in this repo or in a separate repo, it doesn't really matter to me. :smiley:

@jigish If you do end up using the separate repo, I think it makes sense for me to have access to this repo. Another option is to create an organization and move this repo and the new repo for Slate2 into repos under the organization. I know GitHub support is generally happy to do those sorts of things for us.

@sdegutis If you (or anyone) is wanting to go the Lua route, I would recommend just checking out [Hammerspoon](http://www.hammerspoon.org/) and building from there. I've actually already started a pseudo slate rewrite (similar config principles) and would be happy to work with you in going that route. When I try to use a binding with a shell operation, I often get this error:
![slate](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3340/3759505/7774d720-185f-11e4-88f7-c7c8c79d708a.png)

After doing some work to get the subshell to stick around and give me information about its env, it doesn't look like a proper subshell at all.

As a result, many commands that I could otherwise use in my bash shell cannot be used from within slate.

Thoughts? Solutions? Is there a fork or PR somewhere with better shell support?

I haven't looked at this particular part of the code, but I'm pretty sure that the shell being used to execute these commands is a restricted subshell, meaning that it won't pull in any of your normal initialization files such as `.bashrc`, `.profile`, etc. The best way that I know of to address this at the moment is to create a script that you can call out to via a full path that is self-contained (meaning it pulls in, sets, or otherwise manipulates the shell environment how it sees fit in order to run whatever it needs to run).

Hopefully that sheds some light on the issue. I'm not a aware of another fork or a PR that adds the better shell support that you're looking for.
Sourcing a `.bashrc` or trying to set ENV vars still results in the above pop-up error. Any ideas?
I should add that I've tried both absolute paths to the script I want to run as well as relative to the `~`.

Does your script contain calls to binaries without calling _their_ absolute paths?  I've found that to be the cause of some errors for me.  Slate's shell seems to have no $PATH at all, so it often has trouble finding binaries.

Sourcing `~/.bashrc` should fix the $PATH issue, I think. 

One issue is that to use this on different machines, I can't hardcode the absolute path to my dotfile's scripts dir since it might live in a different user's home directory.

Oddly enough, a path like `~/bin/foo` does seem to work occasionally, provided that shell script doesn't try to shell out to anything else. Sourcing .bashrc and/or RVM's\* `~/.rvm/scripts/rvm` script doesn't work. (*since I was trying to use Ruby and thought it was an issue with Ruby gemsets, but have since given that up)

have you determined which shell you are using? I imagine that it might not be bash which could explain why sourcing your bashrc isn't working (run `echo $0` to determine which shell you are using). Wrapping everything you need to run in `bash -c "your stuff here"` might help you get around this.

Make use of a private API to prevent Slate from hanging waiting for
unresponsive apps.

Tested by pausing Google Chrome with a command like `kill -STOP 11019`,
then interacting with Slate (using hot keys to reposition windows). I
observed that there is some lag before the `CGSEventIsAppUnresponsive`
API actually registers the state of the world; it returns `false` at
first, but after about 20 seconds it correctly returns `true`. During
the initial interval, interacting with Slate is laggy; after that, it
becomes snappy.

Resumed Chrome with `kill -CONT 11019`.

Fixes: https://github.com/jigish/slate/issues/140

Thanks to @sdegutis for the tip.

Note: there may be other places that need to check for unresponsiveness before proceeding, but in my initial testing, it seems like all the hangs were happening in the `+[AccessibilityWrapper windowsInApp]` method.

Temporary workaround:

Go into System Preferences > Security & Privacy > Privacy. Select Accessibility from the side menu and remove "Slate" from the right pane. Close and re-open slate. In the right pane, re-enable Slate to have access to Accessibility features.

In the default `.slate` file, there is:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

There are a couple issues with those lines. The problem seems to be that the
window tries to resize before moving, and OSX prevents them from overflowing on
the right or bottom of the screen (only when resizing, nudging works fine). This
means that if the right edge of your window touches the right edge of the
screen, the first line will not work. If the bottom edge of your window touches
the bottom edge of the screen, the second line will not work.

If you move the window away from the right/bottom edge, but less than 10% of
thre screen size (as encoded in the above commands), the increase will be capped
by the distance to the edge. So having the right edge of the window 10px away
from the right edge of the window means the window can only grow by 10px at a
time on the left.

Here are alternative commands that give the correct behaviour:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This does however leaves us in this state:
- When trying to grow the window to overlap the bottom or right of the screen, nothing happens (this is okay).
- You can grow a window to overlap to the left of the screen, it works (which is okay-ish, but inconsistent with behaviour of bottom and right).
- When trying to grow the window to overlap to the top of the screen, it is instead nudge in that direction by the amount it should be grown by. This is weird.

The first two bullet point are not a consequence of the alternative commands, while the third is.

Mavericks allows users with multiple monitors to have apps run in full screen mode on each display. When multiple windows of the same application are open and one of those windows is in full screen mode on one display, trying to focus the full screen window when focus is currently on a different application focuses the last focused window of that application. For example:
- with two displays (D1 & D2)
- D1 has a full screen Chrome window
- D2 has one Finder window and one Chrome window
- focus the Chrome window on D2
- focus the Finder window
- activate window hints
- select the hint for the full screen Chrome window
- focus will go to the window of that application that last had focus (the Chrome window on D2)

Once one window of that application has focus, changing focus to a full screen window of the same application seems to work. Continuing from the above list:
- activate window hints
- select the hint for the full screen Chrome window
- the full screen Chrome window now has focus
Looks like it doesn't matter if the other window is full screen, just that it's on a different display.
Turning off the "Displays have separate Spaces" setting under "System Prefs -> Mission Control" fixes this.

Finder on Mavericks has in interesting new behaviour: when you tell it to move or resize a window via Slate, Finder will actually animate the change, showing the window gliding over from its original to new location (or stretching out to its new size).

Unfortunately, this seems to interfere with commands that _both_ resize and move the window; if a Slate move command requires the window to both change in size and in location, only one of the two will actually take effect. Splitting it into two separate commands (using separate calls to win.resize() and win.move() in JS) doesn't solve the issue. My (untested, uninformed) guess is that Finder's animation is only capable of one transformation at a time, and as long as it's still animating one change, it's discarding calls to perform other window moves/resizes.
I don't see this, probably because I set the hidden preference to disable animations in the finder.  Use TinkerTool.  Your motions should now both work and be faster.
Ah! Yes. That did solve this for me. Thanks.

Yup, but I couldn't figure out how to address the monitors individually. Do I need to know the pixel distance from the primary monitor?  I run a setup with two 24" monitors side by side above my MBP 15" display.

> **Screens**
> 
> Some operations allow you to specify a screen. Here are the list of possible values for screen:
> - Integer representing the screen ID (indexed at 0). Screens are ordered from left to right (by X coordinate of the origin which is the top-left point). If `orderScreensLeftToRight` is set to false, the screen ID is the Mac OS internal ID (indexed at 0). If `orderScreensLeftToRight` is set to false but you still want to reference screens in the default ordered mode, prefix the screen ID with `ordered:`.
> - Screen resolution in the format `WIDTHxHEIGHT` (e.g. `1440x900`)
> - Screen direction relative to the current screen (`left|right|up|above|down|below`)
> - `next` or `previous` (represents the `currentID+1` or `currentID-1` screen)

Assuming the two 24" monitors have the same resolution, you'll need to use the first option to do what you want.

+1 verify this bug. Turning no `persist` for `windowHintsOrder` causes hints to only work once. Reloading/restarting Slate enables another single use. Disabling the `persist` option returns the behavior to normal.

I use Emacs for TODOs (org mode), regular code editing, and gmail (mu4e). I run them in three separate Emacs windows, and they behave pretty much like 3 separate apps. Currently, I can't focus a specific window using Slate. I can only focus the Emacs app as a whole.

You could perhaps imagine a similar use case with Chrome windows, where one window has Gmail open, another a todo list, and the third has many tabs for regular browsing.

Sorry if this is a dupe, I couldn't find another issue describing it.

I'm definitely interested in finding a better way to do this.

@philc 
I currently do this by walking all windows of an application looking for a matching title.
I ended up writing a [runOrRaise](https://github.com/legumbre/dotslatejs/blob/master/slate.js#L39-L93) command which takes an application name and a lambda as a filter and focus only windows matching that filter.
So something like `runOrRaise("Emacs", function (w) { return w.title() == "foo.org"; })` would focus the Emacs frame currently displaying the `foo.org` buffer. 

This is not the best solution but it seems to work pretty well, maybe someone else can use it and improve it, so there.

@jigish 
Thanks for Slate, it's wonderful!

@legumbre the workaround I have now is to have 3 separate Emacs apps in the Apps folder, named Emacs, Orgmode, and Email (you can edit an app's display name by Right clicking, Show Package Contents, edit info.plist in English.proj), each with different icons. Then I can target them by app name with slate.

Under `System Preferences -> Keyboard -> Keyboard Shortcuts` under the `Keyboard & Text Input` group, you can assign a binding to "Move focus to the Dock".

@SethMilliken thanks.. already was aware of the default `Ctrl-F3` binding, but... that solution ends up being a bit awkward.

I would have to `Ctrl-F3` -> `Home` -> `Right Arrow` (x # of times) to simulate a `Cmd-1`, `Cmd-2`, etc type of binding like `Snap` has.

I was hoping that there might be a way to actually invoke an item at a position in the dock.  I'm not an OSX guy, but I assume there must be a way to invoke items in the dock by an index.

One other note -- the `Snap` binding has a behavior that changes.  If the dock app is not running, it starts.  If the dock app is not the current app, it becomes current.  If it is the current app, then it is hidden.  The `focus` behavior of Slate is a little different in that it will always focus the app regardless of whether it's current or not.

It would be interesting to have an easy way to get at dock items by index directly.

I wonder if there's a way to call window.setFrame directly. Is it possible to use `NSAccessibilityWindowAttribute` to get do that?

@WarWithinMe No, the only two that can be used are `NSAccessibilitySizeAttribute` and `NSAccessibilityPositionAttribute`. In [Zephyros](https://github.com/sdegutis/zephyros) I have a function to set the frame of a window, but it technically just sets the size, then the position, then the size again. The extra set-size is needed because sometimes you can't move the window to the right position until it's smaller, and sometimes you can't resize the window to the new size until it's in the right position. So you can just use this technique to get the same results.

Slate is great, and I'm starting to learn my way around the code so I can work on it.

I would like to implement pie menus for Slate in JavaScript/HTML. 
It would be great to be able to do something like this:

http://www.donhopkins.com/home/movies/TabWindowDemo.mov

To that end, I am playing around with exposing the WebView that Slate uses for its JavaScript interpreter. 

Instead of making a hidden WebView in JSController.m, I am making a window in MainWindow.xib, plugging it into SlateAppDelegate, and grabbing it from the JSController.m initialization code. 

So Slate's JavaScript interpreter can create HTML user interfaces in the WebView in the window. 

I need to write some wrappers to make it possible for JavaScript to control the window, show, hide, position, bring to top, etc. 

And also it would be great to figure out how to make a transparent window that only shows through where HTML draws, leaving the background of the web page transparent. 

I'm not sure how easy that is, but it's worth doing if possible. 

It would also be great to flesh out the accessibility and speech recognition APIs, and make it possible to write all kinds of intelligent application automation and integration scripts, bots, with nice HTML user interfaces in JavaScript. Take a look at what Dragon Naturally Speaking has done with Python: 

https://code.google.com/p/dragonfly/

Here are some thoughts and opinion I wrote about window managers, stuff I've done in the past with older systems, and the direction I would like to take Slate, from a discussion on Hacker News:

https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=5861229

X-Windows is a dead end (and has been for a long time), and X window managers are as complex and dug into a pit of pointless complexity as the Space Shuttle.

There are a lot of good reasons to have a scriptable window manager, with a scripting language tightly integrated with the window system.

When I started hacking X10, I wanted to implement pie menus for it. There was a cheezy little library called "XMenu" that was intended for other programs to use to make menus, which I adapted for pie menus, but no programs actually used it, and it was not very configurable (no menu definition language, just an api), plus its model and api was not well suited for pie menus. And once you have menus, you need a way to make selecting their items actually do something!

So I adapted the "uwm" window manager to support pie menus, so you could define your own pie menus and linear menus in your .uwmrc file. Because a window manager could really benefit from pie menus: lots of the commands are spatially oriented and can be arranged in appropriate mnemonic directions, and they have a fixed set of common window management commands that can be thoughtfully arranged into a set of efficient pie menus, as well as a menu definition language to enable users to create custom menus for running apps, connecting with remote hosts, etc.

I wanted to experiment with different styles of menu tracking, mouse ahead, display pre-emption, feedback, screen edge handling, rolling between pie menus and linear menus, invoking window management commands, and stuff like that, and uwm's C code was not very flexible in that regard.

We also wanted to perform a controlled experiment comparing the selection time and error rate of pie menus and linear menus, so I needed to program the window manager to administer the experiment, define and randomize the menus, prompt the user to select from pie and linear menus, time the menu selections, report the statistics, etc.
I had been using Mitch Bradley's "Forthmacs", which was a very nice Forth system for the 68k. (It eventually evolved into the Sun 4 Forth boot ROMS, OpenFirmware, and the OLPC boot ROMs). It was capable of dynamically linking in C code (well not dll's or shared libraries, but it would actually call the linker to relocate the code to the appropriate place in Forth's address space, read in the relocated code, and write Forth wrappers, so you could call C code from Forth, pass parameters, etc -- SunOS 4.2 didn't have relocatable shared libraries or light weight threads back then, so Forth had to do a lot of the heavy lifting to plug in C code. But Forth was a really great way to integrate a library into an interactive extension language, call it from the Forth command line, build on top of C code in Forth, call back and forth between C and Forth, play around with it from the Forth command line, etc).

So I refactored UWM a bit so I could plug it into Forth and rewrite the main loop and event tracking code in Forth, and write higher level menu tracking and window management code in Forth, and administer the experiment in Forth. For example, you could pick up a window and throw it, and it would fork off a light weight Forth task to make it bounce around on the screen! See the "fling" code: 

http://www.donhopkins.com/home/archive/piemenu/uwm1/hacks.f

I didn't realize it at the time, but it foreshadowed what I would later do with NeWS and PostScript.

It was very nice to have a window manager that I could program in Forth, because that was my scripting language of choice at the time, and I could integrate it with C code and Xlib. But then I learned about SunDew aka NeWS (I read the SunDew article in Methodology of Window Management: http://www.chilton-computing.org.uk/inf/literature/books/wm/... and saw Gosling give a talk about it at SUG).

I visited James Gosling, David Rosenthal, Owen Densmore and Mitch Bradley at Sun, who showed me NeWS, and gave me a beta copy to play around with. I learned to program PostScript, and switched from Forth to PostScript for programming windows managers, pie menus and user interfaces. PostScript is a much better language for that than Forth, not only because it has a nice graphics model, but because it's a lot more like Lisp or Smalltalk than Forth, and NeWS extended it with an object oriented programming system that used the dictionary stack to implement inheritance, with which we built user interface toolkits and entire apps, like a visual PostScript programming environment and debugger: 

http://www.donhopkins.com/drupal/?q=node/97

NeWS was architecturally similar to what is now called AJAX, except that NeWS coherently:
- used PostScript code instead of JavaScript for programming.
- used PostScript graphics instead of DHTML and CSS for rendering.
- used PostScript data instead of XML and JSON for data representation.

Some years passed, NeWS was canceled, some other stuff happened, the web came along, the Mac stopped sucking so badly and adopted Unix and NeXT Step, the term AJAX was coined to describe what NeWS was doing all along and what X refused to do for political reasons, and JavaScript took over the world.

So back to real-time: I just recently installed and read the source code of a nice Mac tiling window manager called "Slate": https://github.com/jigish/slate . It look very clean and well designed and even simple, and I think it has a lot of potential! You can program it in JavaScript (it makes an invisible web browser and injects a JavaScript API to the application into it, and delivers events to JavaScript when windows move or change state, calling JavaScript handlers that can call back and manipulate the windows to achieve tiling window layout, and so on and so forth), and it exposes some of the Mac's accessibility API to JavaScript, which brings a lot of power to the table.

Slate is very powerful and flexible, and I'd like to teach it to support pie menus (and other user interface widgetry, maybe by simply popping a web browser up in a window), so you can define pie menus in JSON for window and application management or whatever you want, and script their behavior in JavaScript, and manipulate windows and apps via the accessibility API from JavaScript. Maybe throw in an http server so your window manager can surface web pages and interactive user interfaces in web browsers (that would be a good way to implement pie menus in JavaScript and html, instead of coding them up in Objective C).

I think that Slate takes exactly the right approach with JavaScript, and I hope to get my head around it and do some work with it, like making pie menus for window management, app launching and controlling the accessibility API.

Making the transparent browser window big enough to cover both screens works like a charm! 

One thing I don't know if it's currently possible is to bind mouse clicks to Slate functions -- it only seems to use the names of keys, not mouse buttons. 

But even without that feature, I think an easy way to pop up pie menus in response to click events is to draw some html over or adjacent to the window that you can click on to get the pie menu, and handle all the input tracking in the web browser itself. 

Mouse events that happen over non-transparent parts of the web browser are delivered to the browser, so it should work just fine. 

But it would be nice for the purposes of pie menus to be able to capture mouse clicks (with shift modifiers or without) on windows, and even conditionally pass them on to the app if they're not interesting. Any idea how to do that? 

I've been looking at the accessibility stuff, to figure out what kind of stuff Slate can make applications do, but I haven't dug really deep yet. 

Does the JavaScript/Objective C bridging magic automatically let you get and set properties and call methods on the Objective C Accessibility objects from JavaScript, and drill down to their children? 

Or would more wrappers need to be written to support that? 

There's a lot of surface area to the accessibility API, so it would be great if the bridging was automatically handled, so I didn't have to write millions of wrappers. 

Although it might be necessary to define some of the constants from the .h files in JavaScript at least.

I am excited about the possibilities of being able to implement Slate user interfaces in HTML/JavaScript!

The windowMoved and windowResized notifications to JavaScript were passing in an app wrapper instead of a window wrapper, so I fixed RunningApplications windowChanged to check for kAXWindowCreatedNotification, kAXWindowMovedNotification, kAXWindowResizedNotification, kAXWindowMiniaturizedNotification, kAXWindowDeminiaturizedNotification, kAXMovedNotification and kAXResizedNotification and in those cases call runWindowJSCallbacks (which sends a JSWindowWrapper parameter instead of a JSApplicationWrapper parameter) instead of calling JSController runCallbacks:payload: (which sends a JSApplication parameter), and also I added notification for kAXWindowMiniaturizedNotification and kAXWindowDeminiaturizedNotification. 

I have punched holes in JSWindowWrapper to expose its AccessibilityWrapper, and in AccessibilityWrapper to support manipulating its AXUIElementRef window, including the methods actionNames, performAction:, attributeNames, getAttributeValue:, getAttributeValueCount:, getParameterizedAttributeValue:parameter:, isAttributeSettable:, setAttributeValue:value:, postKeyboardEventKeyChar:virtualKey:keyDown:, and implemented webScriptNameForSelector: and webScriptNameForKey: so they replace :'s in selectors with _'s, so you can call the methods easily from JavaScript. The basic stuff seems to work but there is some more glue code to write, but I think I'm well on the road to bridging a pretty useful subset of the Accessibility API to JavaScript!

Do windows have some kind of constant ID I can use that does not change over time? It would be nice to expose that, so I can keep track of them in JavaScript structures without hanging onto wrapper references. Using window titles is kind of sketchy.

I'm having the same problem with emacs (MacPorts 24.3.1) snapshot activation.  However, I can get window-hinting to work via a workaround. Probably can add a simple shadow underneath the letter?

UPDATE: sorry, have reposted..

Certain apps, when they have focus, can make the menubar invisible/auto-hidden.
This can even be configured for a "regular" app by modifying its .plist file.

When such apps have focus, screenOriginY and screenSizeY should take the extra space available at the top (where the menubar would have been) into account, which they do not at the moment.

The current implementation just uses plain white letters on top of icons in the hinting mode; as a result it can be very difficult to tell the letter for some apps with bright icons. 

I think this can be easily fixed by just adding shadow for the letters in Photoshop / Illustrator...

[I know there have been quite a few 'Fn' key related issues, and they all had to be closed because of problems making the feature work. However I had something to add, and wasn't sure if I would be able to get your attention if I posted to an already closed issue. 
So, I am creating a new issue. Feel free to delete/close this, if it makes sense]

I love Slate. But with some many configurations possible, one soon starts to run out of _convenient_ hotkeys that don't conflict with global ones or those used by other apps. 

And so, allowing Fn as a modifier (with all the combinations possible by combining it with other modifiers), would really be super helpful. And, at the current point, it might be _the_ single-most important feature that enables users to  make Slate an effortless part of their window management workflow -- for any and all types of window management tasks.

FWIW, using KeyRemap4MacBook allows one to bind to the Fn+key or Fn+modifier(s)+key type shortcuts. Even on Mountain Lion. Which means that it should be possible, in theory, for Slate to be able to allow Fn based based bindings as well.

The core functionality of KeyRemap4MacBook is provided as a kernel extension. This presents a vastly different model of installation and authorization than Slate: Launching the Slate app vs launching the KeyRemap4MacBook installer, providing admin credentials, going through the installation procedure, and then rebooting (after which you are at risk of provoking kernel panics). Don't get me wrong, KeyRemap4MacBook is great; but it's a different class of tool. I doubt it would be worthwhile for Slate to make the same sort of compromises. Plus, there's nothing stopping you from using them together.

FWIW, using Slate's `modal-key`s can help greatly with available bindings.

@SethMilliken: Agree with you for the most part. However, KeyRemap4MacBook requires admin privileges only once, during installation. So as far as inconvenience goes (ignoring security aspects), its hardly an issue. Also, it might be worth investigating if admin privileges are required specifically for the Fn functionality (though I have a hunch it they would be, as well).
Using modal-key is a great option, I agree. I did not know about it, so thanks! But its not as seamless as an action that did not require switch modes etc.
Regarding using KeyRemap with Slate: Not a bad idea (I had thought earlier of doing that myself), but it still requires hotkeys to first be created using Slate, and mapping other (Fn-based) ones to those using KeyRemap. And these Slate hotkeys could still conflict/potentially conflict with other hotkeys, unless one choses really random/weird combinations that are unlikely to be used by the system/other app... but that's far from an ideal solution as far as I am concerned.

Having said that, I agree that you make useful points. If gigish/anyone else authorized to do so feels that the issue should be closed, they can go ahead and do that.

Typically you use [NSDisableScreenUpdates()](https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Cocoa/Reference/ApplicationKit/Miscellaneous/AppKit_Functions/Reference/reference.html#//apple_ref/c/func/NSDisableScreenUpdates) to pause drawing and [NSEnableScreenUpdates()](https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Cocoa/Reference/ApplicationKit/Miscellaneous/AppKit_Functions/Reference/reference.html#//apple_ref/c/func/NSEnableScreenUpdates) to resume drawing. This makes window repositioning look atomic and super smooth. But this only works for the windows in your process. However, using [mach_inject](https://github.com/rentzsch/mach_inject), using the PIDs of the apps that own the windows you're moving, you could force those apps to call these functions.

However, all the icons were then spread on top of each other. I set `windowHintsSpread` to `true`, to spread the icons out, however, they're then all laid out in a single vertical line, starting from the middle of the screen, and running off the bottom of the screen.

Is there some way of laying out the Window Hints in a grid, say?

Cheers,
Victor

As far as I know there is no grid option, but u can change the fact that they appear starting in the middle and go down, and hence some get cut off the screen.
e.g.
`config windowHintsShowIcons true`
`config windowHintsIgnoreHiddenWindows false`
`config windowHintsSpread true`
`config windowHintsSpreadPadding 15`   # pixel gap between icons
`config windowHintsDuration 5`               # how long hints stay on the screen
`config windowHintsHeight 75`                # the size of the hints. You can make them smaller so more will fit
`config windowHintsWidth 75`
`config windowHintsTopLeftX windowSizeX/5`  # position of where they appear relative to the window
`config windowHintsTopLeftY windowSizeY/5`  # if u set both X and Y to 0 the hint will show at the top left corner of a window and more hints would fit in the vertical line

:+1: as having small icons + enabled spread + set to `0` `TopLeftX` and `TopLeftY` doesn't resolve the problem

The window's title bar sticks up into the upper half of the screen leaving a gab of the window's title bar's height below the window. Or am I doing something wrong here?

Couple comments and questions:
1. it really should be `bind esc:cmd move screenOriginX;screenOriginY+screenSizeY*0.5 screenSizeX;screenSizeY*0.5 1` because `0,0` is the top-left of the main screen (the one with the menu bar). it is always a good idea to use `screenOriginX` and `screenOriginY` because they take into account multiple monitors, the dock, the menu bar and such.
2. What application is this? When you say "the window's title bar sticks up into the upper half of the screen" can you manually (with your mouse) move the title bar off the window's content? If so, they are likely two different windows.
3. Can I get a before and after screenshot please? It will help me better understand what is happening.

1. OK, so it's a user error. Using screenOrigin is reasonable.
2. Any application, eg Finder. Maybe I put it wrong. With "sticking up" I just meant that the window is placed a bit too high and by roughly the height of the title bar.
3. No need to further investigate in this, it really was a misunderstanding on my part, sorry for the hassle.

When you bind an action to a keystroke and hit that key, the action only gets run when the active application has a window.

Example: Safari is the active app and has a browser window open, then hitting the key will run the action. When Safari has no windows open, hitting the key will not run the action.

should be simple enough if we create pass-through methods in objective-c. do this for `JSInfoWrapper`, `JSWindowWrapper`, `JSScreenWrapper`, `JSOperationWrapper` and `JSApplicationWrapper`.
done.

currently we can create operations in a pseudo `one-off` manner by using `slate.operation` but that internally creates an operation object. To prevent memory bloat, we need something like `slate.doOperation(name, options)` and `windowObject.doOperation(name, options)`. This will do the operation without actually creating an object preventing any bloat in memory from random operation objects floating around (that should be cleaned up in GC but who knows).
done

Whereas screenOriginX and Y take into account the size and position of the Dock and the Menubar, screen.rect().x and .y do not.

Similarly, screen.rect().height and .width report the full dimensions of the screen, not the available dimensions after subtracting the area occupied by the Dock and Menubar.

Is this intentional/working as designed? If so, would it be possible to add some other way to check access the Dock/Menu-adjusted values?

so this is working as intended so that you can get the actual resolution of the screen.

you make a good point, though. I'll add a `screen.visibleRect()` method to get the visible dimensions of the screen. That will take into account Dock and Menubar.
added. will be in the next version.
Wonderful! Thanks a lot.
Would it be possible to add a function to the JS Window object that returns whether or not a window is resizable?

Not yet. From the accessibility API there isn't actually a way to check if a window is movable/resizable. You pretty much have to try to move it and see if it works. If it doesn't work it'll throw an exception which I catch internally and then most of the time I'll return `false` on the `operation.run()` or `window.doOperation()` method.

I'll try to add a function that tries to "move" the window to the same location that it is to see if it can be moved as well as a function that tries to "resize" the window to the same size it is to see if it can be resized. Sort of awkward, but it should work.

It's not a high priority thing for me. In the situation where I'm envisioning using it, I could just as easily check the return value for `window.doOperation()` and add a fall-back that moves the window without resizing it.
fair enough. it is done either way :). isMovable and isResizable are methods on the window object. I'll push a new version some time today with the change.

Yah, "screen" means physical screen. Also the default hint behavior is to order the hints left to right. Check out the config "windowHintsOrder" in the readme for more details. I'm using slate as a replacement for SizeUp, I was wondering how can I make slate to center a window like SizeUp `ctrl+alt+cmd C`

I thought that using the `corner` command would be the best way to achieve this, but when using corner you cannot specify the coordinates for the origin of the window ( you're limited to `top-left` ... right ... etc. )

Any ideas ?

should be something like this:

`bind c:ctrl,alt,cmd move screenOriginX+((screenSizeX-windowSizeX)/2);screenOriginY+((screenSizeY-windowSizeY)/2) windowSizeX;windowSizeY`

That will center the window on the current screen.

Here's an AppleScript that might help simplify managing config files a little. Run it twice to see what it does. The first time it creates a folder in your home folder called "Slate Sets" and puts a backup of your .slate file into that folder. (I don't know how to use the markup at GitHub, but if you copy the entire text of the script, it should compile OK in AppleScript Editor, at least it did for me.)

Next time you run it, it lets you make a choice from whatever files exist in the Slate Sets folder and replaces the .slate file with the one you selected, then relaunches Slate to activate that one.

Even if you cancel changing config files, it makes sure Slate is running from the most recently loaded one.

So if you make changes or add any files to the Slate Sets folder, you can load the new ones quickly, no matter what  the file name is. One of the things it doesn't do yet is to provide the name of the last file you activated.

(The above assumes you're already using a .slate file. If you aren't, it performs the operation of creating one from default settings before it performs either of the actions described above, so you would need to run it 3 times to observe its full functionality.)

---

set default_settings to "# This is the default .slate file.

# If no ~/.slate file exists this is the file that will be used.

config defaultToCurrentScreen true
config nudgePercentOf screenSize
config resizePercentOf screenSize

# Resize Bindings

bind right:alt       resize +10% +0
bind left:alt        resize -10% +0
bind up:alt          resize +0   -10%
bind down:alt        resize +0   +10%
bind right:ctrl;alt  resize -10% +0 bottom-right
bind left:ctrl;alt   resize +10% +0 bottom-right
bind up:ctrl;alt     resize +0   +10% bottom-right
bind down:ctrl;alt   resize +0   -10% bottom-right

# Push Bindings

bind right:ctrl;cmd  push right bar-resize:screenSizeX/3
bind left:ctrl;cmd   push left  bar-resize:screenSizeX/3
bind up:ctrl;cmd     push up    bar-resize:screenSizeY/2
bind down:ctrl;cmd   push down  bar-resize:screenSizeY/2

# Nudge Bindings

bind right:shift;alt nudge +10% +0
bind left:shift;alt  nudge -10% +0
bind up:shift;alt    nudge +0   -10%
bind down:shift;alt  nudge +0   +10%

# Throw Bindings

bind 1:ctrl;alt         throw 0 resize
bind 2:ctrl;alt         throw 1 resize
bind 3:ctrl;alt         throw 2 resize
bind right:ctrl;alt;cmd throw right resize
bind left:ctrl;alt;cmd  throw left  resize
bind up:ctrl;alt;cmd    throw up    resize
bind down:ctrl;alt;cmd  throw down  resize

# Focus Bindings

bind right:cmd    focus right
bind left:cmd     focus left
bind up:cmd       focus up
bind down:cmd     focus down
bind up:cmd;alt   focus behind
bind down:cmd;alt focus behind

# Window Hints

bind esc:cmd hint"

set myHome to ((path to home folder) as string)
set _path to myHome & "Slate sets:"
set targ1 to POSIX path of _path
set targ2 to POSIX path of myHome
set user_dotSlate to (targ2 & ".slate")
try
    set name_target to alias (POSIX file (user_dotSlate)) --file name is already taken at destination if no error occurs.
    try
        set name_target to alias (POSIX file (targ1 & "originaldotslate")) --file name is already taken at destination if no error occurs.
    on error
        my backupdotslate(user_dotSlate, (targ1 & "original.slate"))
    end try

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

on error
    do shell script ("echo \"" & default_settings & space & "\" > " & space & (user_dotSlate))
end try

on backupdotslate(original_Slate, backup_Target)
    set thesource to (quoted form of (POSIX path of original_Slate))
    do shell script "ditto" & space & thesource & space & quoted form of backup_Target
end backupdotslate

on bounce_Slate()
    tell application "Slate" to activate
    do shell script "sleep 1"
    tell application "Slate" to quit
    do shell script "sleep 1"
    try
        tell application "Slate" to activate
    end try

## end bounce_Slate

What action could be used to push a window that isn't resizeable such as System Preferences to a corner at the right of the screen to ensure that its right edge meets screen edge, either top or bottom?

Is it possible to indicate push locations by specifying and referencing a grid formula, such as defining a grid of 12X8 then specifying the location for the window as row 1-3 starting at column 9?

Thanks.

The problem is that when making a window that can be resized move to a corner, not setting the size set for the window doesn't yield optimal results. But when you apply that strategy to a window like System Preferences that can't be resized, the size formula probably wouldn't make it go to the right place if the destination corner is on the right side.  Rather than configuring separate sets of corner pushing shortcuts for resizeable and non-resizable windows, I used a sequence to try to apply the size constraints first, then push to the indicated corner. Top left needs only the formula, but the other 3 corners need the sequence. This assumes that displaying the whole window for windows that can't be resized takes priority over how much of the screen is occupied by the window. Here's an example

alias topleft corner top-left resize:screenSizeX/2;screenSizeY/2
alias topright move screenOriginX+screenSizeX/2;screenOriginY screenSizeX/2;screenSizeY/2
alias bottomleft corner bottom-left resize:screenSizeX/2;screenSizeY/2
alias bottomright corner bottom-right resize:screenSizeX/2;screenSizeY/2

bind 1:ctrl;alt;cmd sequence ${topleft} 
bind 2:ctrl;alt;cmd sequence ${topright} > push up > push right
bind 3:ctrl;alt;cmd sequence ${bottomleft} > push down > push left
bind 4:ctrl;alt;cmd sequence ${bottomright} > push down > push right

I  forgot to remove "sequence" for top left binding in the above.

bind 1:ctrl;alt;cmd ${topleft}

The beauty of Slate is that it's completely customisable, so you can set all the keybindings yourself - the default config does indeed take over your alt+left/right and cmd+left/right, which is why you're missing out on standard OS X text selection.

You should create a new file in your home directory called `.slate` and then start adding your own bindings there.

Alternatively, you can copy the default config to your home directory and make changes as needed, which can be done by running the following command:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

@josh- is correct. Using the default `.slate` file you'll lose a lot of those bindings. If you want to remove them or change them copying the `default.slate` to `~/.slate` is the way to go. You can then mess with the bindings yourself and update them to whatever you want.

I learnt today that you can specify a style for `throw`... From `README.md`:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

It seems to me that `resize` with no parameter causes the window to be maximised in the new screen after the throw, whereas `resize` with parameters allows resizing, relative to the new screen's dimensions.

I suggest adding a `proportional` mode which resizes the window so that it occupies the same proportion of the new screen as it does of the old one.

So, suppose I have two screens; screen 0 is 500x1000 whereas screen 1 is 2000x3000.  And suppose I have a window on screen 0 whose width is 250 and height is 750 - so it is 50% of the width and 75% of the height of screen 0; when thrown to screen 1, it would resize to 1000x2250.

(IIRC this is, btw, SizeUp's default behaviour.)

I suppose another way to do this would be to allow it to be calculated in the config, and using `resize:x;y` style.  However, at present I don't think it's possible because the old screen's dimensions are unavailable?  (Would `windowSizeX` and `windowSizeY` refer to pre-throw window size correctly here?)

However, the use case I've described is perhaps obvious and common enough to warrant its own style?

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

However, that seems not to happen at the moment; I presume that's because aliases are expanded as strings, so we end up with:

and it's completely unclear/ill-defined which `chain` or `sequence` operations each `|` belongs to.  I don't even know what the actual parse tree is in this case.  Is it just going left-to-right?  If so, then I guess it's equivalent to:

2. The window's width is _not_ constrained to 1680, and remains at 1920.

Now, that would be OK, if hitting Ctrl-Alt-Cmd-`m` again caused the window to maximise on its new screen. But it doesn't! It has no effect at all, it seems.  That strikes me as a bug.

I've got around this with the following kludge:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

i.e., precede the maximise operation with one which reduces the window's width to 50% of the screen's; this works, and I was happy with it. But for reasons I will elaborate on in another bug report, it's no longer so satisfying, so I thought I'd raise this issue separately, in case it's of interest (and to reduce confusion in the other report).

yah I've noticed this too. OS X doesn't like resizing windows when either 1. the window is off the screen or 2. the resize causes the window to go off the screen. as a result the current move operation does something like this since you can't both move and resize the window at the same time:
1. resize the window
2. move the window
3. resize again in case the first resize fails

OR
1. move the window
2. resize the window
3. move the window again in case the resize was awkward

I have to think of a better way to do this. I think this should work:
1. resize the window to something tiny like 1,1
2. move the window assuming the size will be perfectly what is in the binding
3. resize the window (OS X may resize to something that is slightly off - explained below)
4. move the window again no longer assuming what the size will be

"The window's height is automatically constrained to the new screen's height (Chrome goes to 1046, for example - not sure why it's not 1050)."

There a couple reasons why this could be:
1. You have a hidden dock on the bottom of the screen. OS X is funny about how large it says the screen is. If there is a dock, it will cut off some pixels and say that your 1050 screen is actually more like 1046. Super irritating, I agree and technically I may be able to fix this but I think it may be more trouble than what it is worth.
2. The application itself refuses to be sized to 1050. This happens a lot with text editors and terminals. They don't liked to be sized such that a line is cut in half so they force the height/width to be a multiple of the font height/width.

_nods_ - hidden Dock in my case, and yes, have seen this with terminals, etc. too.  It's no problem really.

Sounds a bit hairy.  With my approach, you can perceive the two resizes, although I've made it seem smoother by resizing to 90% of screen width rather than 50% - though of course that's no general solution, I can just do it because I'm maximising in this case.  I wonder if, with your proposed approach, we'd notice the stages?

you most definitely would. It would happen quick, but you'd _definitely_ see the stages. unfortunate, but currently the only way I can see to ensure proper moving/resizing.

though now that I think about it, I could _calculate_ whether the window is or will be off screen and adjust my approach accordingly. thought this seems like it would probably introduce a ton of corner cases and bugs. I feel like one single approach that works in all cases would probably be better.

So I got this to work sort of, but not as ideal or as generic as I'd like. 

`bind pad4:cmd,alt,ctrl,shift chain push left bar-resize:screenSizeX/2 | throw next resize:screenSizeX/2;screenSizeY`

There are two uses cases that are not currently covered with this command. 

### A user with more than two monitors.

Let's say a user has three monitors. On the third key press in the chain, there are no more commands so Slate loops back to the original command (which is simply to resize the window without moving to the next monitor). So essentially that third key press doesn't do anything since the window is already resized left from the previous throw next command. 

You have to press it again to move to the next command in the chain which actually throws to the next monitor. 

You could work around this by adding another command to the chain repeating the throw next command, but that requires updating the config file depending on how many monitors you have and still runs into the second use case issue...

### You change your mind and want the window on the original monitor.

As mentioned in the previous use case, when you loop the chain command, that first command doesn't do anything. 

So if you want to bring the window back to the original monitor after initiating the chain you have to press it four times (assuming you have just two monitors) instead of three. 
1. Resize left on first monitor. 
2. Resize left on second monitor. 
3. (chain repeats) and resizes left on current monitor (but window is already resized left). 
4. Resize left on first monitor. 

The question then is there a way to work around these two use cases? Primarily the second one?

I've finally gotten around to implementing this. Here is how it works:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I'll update the readme soon. Basically adding ":toggle" to the end of any modal binding will make that modal binding toggled. You can also do this:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

implemented an initial version of this. It keeps a stack of snapshots and updates the stack every time you activate a movement related binding in slate. by default the max stack size is 10, but this is configurable through `undoMaxStackSize`. I'll upload a new version later today with this. let me know if there are any issues.
also, just to reiterate - this will _not_ work for focus or visibility related operations and may very well screw up the focus ordering of windows.

oh no you're right. if chain isn't in undoOps then it won't make the snapshot the first time around. yah that just won't work lol. I actually don't know if this is even possible with the current implementation of undo/chain. I wonder if anyone else has implemented this sort of functionality?

But what does _undoing a chain_ mean?

Since `chain` is combining multiple operations to one, I'm not sure whether letting the chain operation be undo'ed or not makes sense at all. It also conflicts with the phrase "you can undo only movement-based operations" because chain itself has nothing to do with movement.
You can't _undo the whole chained operations at one_ either, because it's circular.

How about removing chain from undoOps completely and
checking whether there are any other undoOps _inside_ the command?

I haven't been compeltely paying attention to this, or to how undo is implementing, but I just wanted to butt in with some general thoughts, which may or may not be helpful...

The usual way to handle undo is to build a stack of undo-able operations as they're performed, and then when you undo it simply pops operation items from the stack and applies their inverse (so you can only undo operations whose inverse you can compute (perhaps by explicitly storing prior state) and it's not in general possible to undo operations which have side effects, such as performing shell commands). I don't think chaining has any special effect here, because as you progress through a chain performing operations, it would just push commands onto the stack in the usual fashion? Or am I missing something?

`sequence` is a bit more interesting than `chain` because here we have multiple operations performed in aggregate; but that's OK, you just push onto the stack a special sequence container with each of the composite operations referenced from it, and if you undo/pop that operation, it just goes through the operations in the sequence in reverse, applying their inverses in the usual manner - with the usual caveats that certain operations have no well-defined inverse/undo.

I realise I might be talking about completely reimplementing how you do undo - but this is how I'd do it, anyway. :-)

Thanks.

Basically these files are a mapping of key name (to use in the .slate file) to key code. you can get key codes using this handy application: http://manytricks.com/keycodes/

Adding a new layout would consist of adding a new .plist, then changing `Binding.m`'s method `asciiToCodeDict` do add the new layout. You'd also have to add a new keyboard layout string constant as well (e.g. `KEYBOARD_LAYOUT_DVORAK`).

When using `move screenOriginX;screenOriginY screenSizeX;screenSizeY` with a hidden menu bar (as enabled with [MenuAndDockless](http://createlivelove.com/79/menuanddockless-20/) or [MenuBarHider](https://github.com/Crazor/MenuBarHider)), there is a small strip of unused space at the very top of the screen where the menu bar would live.  

Ideally, there would be a config option to use the whole screen.

`screenOrigin` is accounting for the menubar. `screenSize` however does not. Just change your configuration to `move screenSizeX;screenSizeY screenSizeX;screenSizeY` and you have the whole screen available.

`move screenSizeX;screenSizeY screenSizeX;screenSizeY` puts the window at the bottom of the screen. (Ironically, it sticks up about the height of the menu bar, otherwise I would have been very confused.)

`move screenSizeX;0 screenSizeX;screenSizeY` works for me, but only because my monitors are in a line from left to right and the same resolution.  That is sufficient for my use case, however.

I just installed Slate earlier tonight and it has already earned its place in my login items. I thought there might be a way to map back to the "send front window to back of current app's windows" operation onto command-backtick (that is, cmd-`) like it was in older Mac OS X releases, but unfortunately have not been able to find any to do it. Can I make a feature request for this behavior?

**Rambling background for why I want this:**
_In older releases of Mac OS X, command-backtick was reserved for "send frontmost window to back of current app's windows". This made perfect sense as command-shift-backtick did the exact reverse, i.e. "push backmost window of current app's windows to the front" operation (and it in fact still does this operation)._

_Command-backtick changed in I think 10.5 or 10.6 to a strange hybrid that goes something like:_ 
- _make `n`th-from-front window into frontmost, incrementing `n` for subsequent operations..._
- _...but reset `n` if you click anywhere or if you switch applications;_
- _and if you're using Safari, also reset `n` if certain javascript/flash events fire in the frontmost window!_

_This has some annoying results for me. If you open three windows 1, 2, and 3; you can repeatedly perform the sequence "command-backtick; click somewhere in the front window" to alternate between windows 1 and 2 without ever bringing 3 to the front. There have been several new releases of OS X since this behavior changed to the current version that I dislike, so I have kinda given up hope of it being changed back._

On non-US keyboards there are a variety of non-ASCII characters which can be typed with a single keypress; for example, Apple's British keyboards have a "§" just below the escape key (where the backtick would be on a US keyboard). It'd be great to be able to use those keys for bindings too, particularly because they are extremely unlikely to be used by other keychord-intensive apps.

Another option would be for me to add a config directive that you can use to specify additional keys and their corresponding key code. This may work well as a temporary solution.
Perhaps you could support a syntax in the config file for specifying the key code directly, e.g. `[1243]`.
True. That would remove the need for yet another config and you can always use aliases to make it prettier. I like it.

I can also imagine a perverse scheme where you'd fire all possible key codes into a hidden text field, and see what characters come out -- you could then create a look-up table mapping characters back to key codes... bleurgh!

While this isn't an ideal solution, you can write to /Applications/Slate.app/Contents/Resources/ASCIIToCode.plist (or one of the others if you're using a different keyboard variant) and enter key/integer pairs for any keystroke; you can then refer to that key in Slate config files. I've only tried this with Slate JavaScript configs.

If you're looking for a list of key codes, this isn't the worst place to start: https://github.com/tekezo/KeyRemap4MacBook/blob/version_8.3.0/src/bridge/generator/keycode/data/KeyCode.data (note that KR4MB uses hex and Slate decimal).

Incidentally, you aren't confined to real keys: you can tell Slate to listen for an arbitrary key code and generate that with e.g. KR4MB. That's the method I'm using to avoid chord conflicts between Slate and other applications.

An operation similar to `chain`, but simpler in that it allows a binding to execute all pipe-delimited operations sequentially in a single invocation.

USE CASE: A `throw` operation that both resizes _and_ repositions the window.

EXAMPLE: with the proposed `sequence` operation:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I could imagine useful scenarios involving adding a `nudge` a `focus` or even a `hint` to a sequence, too (e.g. throw the current window to another screen and then focus a window that had been obscured by the moved window in preparation for the next operation).

An `IGNORE_FAIL` option would probably be appropriate for this, as well.

Sounds like a good idea.

The issue with doing this with something like `hint` is that `hint` breaks the current event loop while waiting for the input so you'd have to restrict `hint` to being the last operation.

Either way I like it and I'll try to implement it soon. Should be pretty easy because the basis is already there with the `chain` operation
Done. will be in 1.0.6 which I'm pushing shortly

Couple of things here
1. `windowHintsIgnoreHiddenWindows` is only for the Window Hints feature. It is meant to ignore windows that are not visible on the screen

I'm trying to find some shortcuts to focus between windows, and reading issue #67 was very useful in understanding how "focus left" and "focus right" work. Unfortunately I don't understand the difference between "up"  and "above", and between "down" and "below".

I have two identically windows from the same application stacked one over the other, and I wanted to use "focus behind" to switch between them. So up and above are the same thing. above is an alias for up. Same with down and below.

Behind is a bit quirky. It will try to focus a window whose z-index is lower and is behind the current window. A lot of the window selection is based on titles and such so if you have a lot of windows layered on top of each other it won't work very well. I would suggest only using behind when you have two windows on top of each other.

O boy. To be completely honest I never expected slate to gain the popularity it has lol. I built it mainly for myself as a replacement to Divvy because at the time Divvy couldn't move windows across monitors and it kind of spiraled into what it is today from there. As far as documentation to build it, I unfortunately don't have any. Nor do I have any documentation in the code (though I have a couple issues for myself to add documentation and unit tests - #97 and #98).

As far as building goes -- You need to get the latest Xcode. Slate uses ARC which is why you're getting all the undeclared identifier __bridge all over the place. Thats an ARC specific directive that tells the compiler that the code I am referencing is non-ARC. Once you get the latest Xcode, the target "Slate" should build it. I also have a ruby script that can generate the .tar.gz and the .dmg in script/slate.rb. Basically run `script/slate.rb gen` and it will generate everything and throw it into the build/Release folder. There are some dependancies though (one of which is a git submodule) so you may need to look through the script and make sure you have it all.

Sorry I can't be of more help. I'm trying to get things documented but slate has grown to a size that it is a pretty large task now lol.

@jigish But suppose hypothetically that I got Xcode 4.2 via some means and then tried to build the project again. I'd, uh, _probably_ get errors like the following:

hmm. thats a good question. I'm using Xcode 4.5 so i'm not getting that error. From what I can tell it would be complaining about how the properties are declared for some reason. Probably adding something like `(strong)` after `@property` would fix it. This would be a problem most likely fixed by Apple's compiler upgrades since 4.2.

I think you're right. Adding (strong) made the error go away. I read briefly about the issue and it does seem that there was a change in ARC in later versions of Xcode. Xcode 4.2 starts out with 7 errors initially, but as files compile successfully after being fixed in the above way, those lower in the dependency chain that were previously not touched then start giving similar errors, creating a cascade of errors that will take forever (or "too long for me" :p) to fix.

Well ok, I guess it's back to the Snow Leopard vs Mountain Lion internal debate. Not to turn this into a os-war tangent, but it does kind of suck that with Apple's recent directions, there is no longer a clear choice for best OS anymore :(

In the off-chance I decide to go for the upgrade, here's the basic design I considered:
- Add a new config called "focusOnLayoutOperation" that can be true or false
- Inside activateLayout in LayoutOperation.m, check for the config value and if true, iterate windowsArrRef and bring each one into focus

Of course, I have no clue if there are any details that disqualify this design since I haven't looked too closely, but would you say something like that is reasonable?

So actually I thought it would be kind of elegant to use the ordering of the directives in the .slate file to be the order in which the windows are focused. So the last one specified would be the last focused and therefore the one that is focused at the end of the layout operation. This way we have consistent behavior regardless of what order the windows are in windowsArrRef. I actually may get around to this today so you may not have to worry about Snow Leopard vs Mountain Lion until later in the future :)

This is done. Will be in version 1.0.7 when I push it. The config is called `layoutFocusOnActivate`. I like the first word in the config name to be the operation it touches so it is a bit easier to figure out what they do.

Basically, if set to true, it will focus all windows that the layout operation touches in the order that it touches them. The order will be the order in which the applications are configured in the .slate file.
Nice! Many thanks!

Keyboard chording is something I try and do as little of as possible to keep my RSI at bay.  As such, I had my Divvy setup configured with only application-wide shortcuts, and F6 launched the Divvy window.  The paradigm became: F6 then 0, to quickly shove my browser window up to the top-right corner, or F6 then 1 to take up the whole screen, or F6 then 6 to give me a centered window, etc.  All of the commands were single keystroke arrangements, but prefixed by the mode-trigger F6.

A benefit of this is that I was able to map out many many window sizes and placements without really impacting the global key command space.  The entire number row and the entire top row of the keyboard are all mapped to a few different things.   The mapping would simplify greatly using your layouts and snapshots feature, but my personal preference would still be to have a modal interface rather than a chorded.  (cough _vimuser_ :-)

I'm pretty sure I'm an outlier here, and that it might just be a major rework of your code to support a feature like this, but I thought I'd drop it in the suggestion box anyway...for a rainy day.

Thanks again for a well done window manager!

The primary goal was to allow for sophisticated (read: user-programmed) event handlers. Then, Tristan proposed being able to have a DSL do the configuration too.  Both are good goals.  Now,  the issues are:
1. Is the DSL for configuration different from the programmability language?  If so, I should think it would need a huge justification.  The complexity of supporting two languages (both implementation and FAQ) seems to outweigh the idea of two.
2. Assuming there is one language, do we invent one of our own? IT doesn't matter if it's a subset of another known language, it'll just be different. Again, unless someone has a huge justification for this, we should go with something well-known in its entirety.
3. Assuming that we will be using something well-known, what baggage will the language implementation bring in? From the time a keystroke is received to when the effects of the event handler are fully visible, it has to be fast. You can't page in megabytes.  You can't run a garbage collector multiple times. Are there other programming-model impediments that we would bring in?
4. And then there's the features of the implementation.  Do we want some sort of OO language?  Is type-safety relevant? What about other features of the runtime? Is network access important?  File system?  Multithreading?

The DSL would definitely be in the scripting language, and the language would definitely be a popular one. There are options that would be really easy to embed and use like F-Script and Nu but they are not well known.

MacRuby is LLVM compiled to some extent and uses Objective-C classes directly so there is little to no lag translating the objects.

The server idea is interesting and has some significant advantages, I definitely agree that it would have to be forked into some separate Daemon or something though. It is an interesting idea for a project, maybe a fork of Slate, a socket interface for the mac accessibility API or something. However, that is something to discuss maybe in another issue/fork.

The advantage of a language embedded right in is it allows a DSL so users can configure Slate in a familiar language, it would also make adding new commands slightly easier because no parsing code would be required. However, it also allows for advanced users to code more complex behaviours.

Here is a working branch with JavaScript bindings: https://github.com/mgax/slate/tree/javascript and a build: http://grep.ro/quickpub/slate/2013-01-19/.

In addition to `~/.slate`, you can create `~/.slate.js`, which gets executed in a WebScripting context. There is a `slate` global object with a few methods:
- `log(message)` - print a message using NSLog.
- `bind(keystroke, callback, repeat)` - register a binding that will invoke the given JavaScript function.
- `resize(x, y)`, `nudge(x, y)`, `focus(x, y)` - perform these operations.
- `relaunch()` - restart Slate to reload configuration.

This is what a configuration file might look like: https://gist.github.com/4569350.

I actually prefer string key definitions, they are shorter and more expressive, reminiscent of CSS selectors. The whole binding syntax is inspired by Backbone [event delegation](http://backbonejs.org/#View-delegateEvents) for views.

What sort of extra bindings do you have in mind? Here's one possible approach: Keep a simple API for JavaScript, basically a thin wrapper around `RegisterEventHotKey` and `activateBinding:isRepeat:`, and implement more complex constructs in JavaScript, where it's easier to experiment.

btw, a little taste of what I've done:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Sort of changed around the syntax and such to make it easier to add new operations. Each operation can be created using the string name then an options hash. The hash can contain functions which will be evaluated at run time or constants which will be stored into the operation at config time. `slate.operation` will instantiate an operation and calling `run` on the returned object will run the operation. This way we don't waste time recreating operations over and over.

ok just pushed my changes. theres a ton of stuff there. here is what is left to make this fully functional (so you only need the `.slate.js`):

- verify/add support for modal keys and implement modal toggle

some additional ideas/notes:
- `config` locally. i.e. setting a config for a particular binding and not for others
- `loop` operation. only available from js. will execute the given operation or function for every window (you'll be able to get the current window info from the function). should probably add an option to only loop through windows in the current app.
- `layout` should really be easier in js than it currently is in the default syntax. I'll try to clean it up when I implement it in js. - `source` should be able to source both normal `.slate` files and `.slate.js` files.
